trans-unit.target: Gestures

trans-unit.source: Intermediate Programmer
trans-unit.target: Intermediate Programmer

trans-unit.source: Gestures are predefined pointer patterns. Stride can recognize gestures and trigger corresponding events. For example, in a strategy game, the player can drag and drop a unit to the battlefield with a drag gesture. Gestures can use one or several fingers.
trans-unit.target: Gestures are predefined pointer patterns. Stride can recognize gestures and trigger corresponding events. For example, in a strategy game, the player can drag and drop a unit to the battlefield with a drag gesture. Gestures can use one or several fingers.

trans-unit.source: !Note All lengths, speeds and error margins of configuration files must use normalized values.
trans-unit.target: !Note All lengths, speeds and error margins of configuration files must use normalized values.

trans-unit.source: Turn on gesture recognition
trans-unit.target: Turn on gesture recognition

trans-unit.source: By default, the input system doesn't recognize gestures, as this requires CPU time.
trans-unit.target: By default, the input system doesn't recognize gestures, as this requires CPU time.

trans-unit.source: To turn on gesture recognition:
trans-unit.target: To turn on gesture recognition:

trans-unit.source: Create an instance of the configuration class for the gesture you want to recognize. For example, for the drag gesture, create an instance of @'Stride.Input.GestureConfigDrag'.
trans-unit.target: Create an instance of the configuration class for the gesture you want to recognize. For example, for the drag gesture, create an instance of @'Stride.Input.GestureConfigDrag'.

trans-unit.source: Configure the class parameters.
trans-unit.target: Configure the class parameters.

trans-unit.source: Add the gesture configuration to the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection.
trans-unit.target: Add the gesture configuration to the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection.

trans-unit.source: !Warning After you activate recognition for a gesture, you can't modify the gesture's parameters. If you need to do this, delete the gesture from the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection and create a new entry with new parameters.
trans-unit.target: !Warning After you activate recognition for a gesture, you can't modify the gesture's parameters. If you need to do this, delete the gesture from the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection and create a new entry with new parameters.

trans-unit.source: Turn off gesture recognition
trans-unit.target: Turn off gesture recognition

trans-unit.source: Delete the gesture from the InputManager.Gestures collection.
trans-unit.target: Delete the gesture from the InputManager.Gestures collection.

trans-unit.source: Gesture recognition
trans-unit.target: Gesture recognition

trans-unit.source: When the input system detects a gesture, it adds a @'Stride.Input.GestureEvent' to the list of InputManager.GestureEvents. The event contains information about the gesture and its state, such as its location and the number of fingers used.
trans-unit.target: When the input system detects a gesture, it adds a @'Stride.Input.GestureEvent' to the list of InputManager.GestureEvents. The event contains information about the gesture and its state, such as its location and the number of fingers used.

trans-unit.source: !Note Each gesture has its own associated gesture event class (see below).
trans-unit.target: !Note Each gesture has its own associated gesture event class (see below).

trans-unit.source: The GestureEvent.Type field indicates which gesture has been recognized. You can then cast the base gesture event into the gesture-specific event type to have gesture-type-specific information about the event.
trans-unit.target: The GestureEvent.Type field indicates which gesture has been recognized. You can then cast the base gesture event into the gesture-specific event type to have gesture-type-specific information about the event.

trans-unit.source: Stride can detect several gestures simultaneously, so the event list can contain more than one item in an update.
trans-unit.target: Stride can detect several gestures simultaneously, so the event list can contain more than one item in an update.

trans-unit.source: The list is cleared with every update, so you don't need to clear it manually.
trans-unit.target: The list is cleared with every update, so you don't need to clear it manually.

trans-unit.source: Types of gesture
trans-unit.target: Types of gesture

trans-unit.source: Stride supports two main types of gesture:
trans-unit.target: Stride supports two main types of gesture:

trans-unit.source: Discrete gestures (tap, flick, long press) trigger a single event.
trans-unit.target: Discrete gestures (tap, flick, long press) trigger a single event.

trans-unit.source: Continuous gestures (drag and composite) trigger a series of events when the user changes the direction of the gesture.
trans-unit.target: Continuous gestures (drag and composite) trigger a series of events when the user changes the direction of the gesture.

trans-unit.target: Tap gesture

trans-unit.source: The user touches the screen and quickly removes their finger.
trans-unit.target: The user touches the screen and quickly removes their finger.

trans-unit.source: The number of fingers on the screen can't vary during the gesture. To set the number of fingers required for a tap, modify @'Stride.Input.GestureConfig.RequiredNumberOfFingers'.

trans-unit.source: !TIP To distinguish single taps from multi-taps, the system uses latency in tap events. To disable this, set the GestureConfigTap.MaximumTimeBetweenTaps field to 0.
trans-unit.target: !TIP To distinguish single taps from multi-taps, the system uses latency in tap events. To disable this, set the GestureConfigTap.MaximumTimeBetweenTaps field to 0.

trans-unit.target: Translation gesture Scale gesture Rotation gesture

trans-unit.source: The user touches the screen with two fingers and moves them independently.
trans-unit.target: The user touches the screen with two fingers and moves them independently.

trans-unit.source: Configuration class: @'Stride.Input.GestureConfigComposite'
trans-unit.target: Configuration class: @'Stride.Input.GestureConfigComposite'

trans-unit.source: Event class: @'Stride.Input.GestureEventComposite'
trans-unit.target: Event class: @'Stride.Input.GestureEventComposite'

trans-unit.source: The composite gesture requires exactly two fingers on the screen. It's triggered when the system detects one of the three basic actions:
trans-unit.target: The composite gesture requires exactly two fingers on the screen. It's triggered when the system detects one of the three basic actions:

trans-unit.source: Translation: the user translates two fingers together in the same direction.
trans-unit.target: Translation: the user translates two fingers together in the same direction.

trans-unit.source: Scale: the user moves two fingers closer together or further apart.
trans-unit.target: Scale: the user moves two fingers closer together or further apart.

trans-unit.source: Rotation: the user rotates two fingers around a center point.
trans-unit.target: Rotation: the user rotates two fingers around a center point.

trans-unit.source: Gesture states
trans-unit.target: Gesture states

trans-unit.source: A gesture always has one of four states:
trans-unit.target: A gesture always has one of four states:

trans-unit.source: Began
trans-unit.target: Began

trans-unit.source: Changed
trans-unit.target: Changed

trans-unit.source: Ended
trans-unit.target: Ended

trans-unit.source: Occurred
trans-unit.target: Occurred

trans-unit.source: Discrete gestures (tap, flick, long press) always have the state occurred. Continuous gestures (drag and composite) always begin with the state began, followed by any changed states, and end with the ended state.
trans-unit.target: Discrete gestures (tap, flick, long press) always have the state occurred. Continuous gestures (drag and composite) always begin with the state began, followed by any changed states, and end with the ended state.

trans-unit.source: To query the current state of a gesture, use the GestureEvent.State field of the triggered gesture event.
trans-unit.target: To query the current state of a gesture, use the GestureEvent.State field of the triggered gesture event.
